sections.heading: Feature Points
sections.description: Assign points per ultrasound feature and sum for category.

sections.heading: Category and Management
sections.description: Total points determine category; management based on nodule size.

sections.heading: Notes
items: Sum feature points to assign TI-RADS category.
Follow-up intervals are typical; adapt to clinical context and prior stability.
Consider patient factors (age, comorbidities, preferences) before biopsy or follow-up.
Use dedicated thyroid US measurements; if multiple nodules, manage each appropriately.
Punctate echogenic foci are considered suspicious for microcalcifications.

sections.heading: Assessment Categories
sections.description: Standard Lung-RADS assessment categories 0-4X

rows: Prior chest imaging or additional views needed to complete assessment.
Obtain prior imaging or additional LDCT; then reassign final category.
No nodules or nodules with definitely benign features.
Nodules with benign characteristics (e.g., calcified, fat-containing, or clearly benign behavior).
Low-suspicion nodules (e.g., small solid or subsolid nodules with low-risk features).
Intermediate-suspicion nodules (solid or part-solid with concerning size/growth).
LDCT in 3 months; consider PET/CT if solid component >= 8 mm.
High-suspicion nodules (larger/growing solid or part-solid lesions).
Diagnostic chest CT (with or without contrast), PET/CT, and/or tissue sampling; manage clinically.
Category 3 or 4 nodules with additional features concerning for lung cancer (e.g., spiculation, pleural retraction, lymphadenopathy).
Diagnostic chest CT, PET/CT, and/or tissue sampling; manage clinically.

sections.heading: Size-Based Nodule Categories
sections.description: Sizing rules by nodule type

tables.title: Solid Nodules
rows: 6 to <8 mm (baseline) or new 4 to <6 mm
8 to <15 mm (baseline) or new 6 to <8 mm
LDCT in 3 months; consider PET/CT if solid component >= 8 mm
Diagnostic chest CT (with or without contrast), PET/CT, and/or tissue sampling
Category 3 or 4 solid nodules with additional high-risk features
Diagnostic chest CT, PET/CT, and/or tissue sampling

tables.title: Part-Solid Nodules
rows: Total size <6 mm or previously stable >=3 years with solid component <6 mm
Total size >=6 mm with solid component <6 mm; or new part-solid <6 mm
Total size >=6 mm with solid component 6 to <8 mm; or new part-solid >=6 mm
LDCT in 3 months; consider PET/CT if solid component >= 8 mm
Solid component >=8 mm; or new/growing solid component >=6 mm
Diagnostic chest CT (with or without contrast), PET/CT, and/or tissue sampling
Category 3 or 4 part-solid nodules with additional high-risk features
Diagnostic chest CT, PET/CT, and/or tissue sampling

tables.title: Ground-Glass (Non-Solid) Nodules
rows: >=30 mm (baseline) or slowly growing non-solid nodule without solid component
New or growing non-solid nodule >=30 mm
Non-solid nodules with additional high-risk imaging features
Diagnostic chest CT, PET/CT, and/or tissue sampling

sections.heading: Modifiers and Notes
items: Use category 0 when prior imaging or additional chest LDCT is required before assigning a final category.
Modifiers may be applied for significant or clinically relevant non-lung cancer findings (e.g., ?S? for significant other findings, ?C? for clinically significant extrapulmonary findings).
Interval for routine screening remains annual (12 months) for categories 1 and 2.
Growth or emergence of a solid component can upgrade category assignment per size thresholds above.
PET/CT is generally considered when the solid component is >=8 mm.

sections.title: Secondary Pulmonary Lobule
sections.description: HRCT resolution approaches the size of the secondary lobule. Understanding its anatomy is essential to interpret distribution and patterns.
items: Centrilobular core: terminal bronchiole and accompanying artery run in the center of the lobule.
Interlobular septa: contain pulmonary veins and lymphatics; septal thickening produces reticular pattern.
Perilymphatic region: along pleura, fissures, bronchovascular bundles.
Centrilobular region: spared pleura and fissures; nodules here suggest small airway or vascular disease.

images.caption: Centrilobular artery/bronchiole in blue; veins/lymphatics in septa (red).

sections.title: Approach to HRCT
sections.description: Two-axis approach: distribution and pattern.
items: Distribution: upper vs mid vs lower zones; central vs peripheral; perilymphatic vs centrilobular vs random; subpleural vs peribronchovascular.
Pattern categories: reticular/interstitial, nodular, increased attenuation (ground-glass, consolidation, crazy paving), decreased attenuation (emphysema, cysts, mosaic attenuation/air-trapping).
Assess ancillary findings: traction bronchiectasis, architectural distortion, pleural disease, lymph nodes, airway caliber, vascular size.

sections.title: Reticular Pattern & Honeycombing
sections.description: Septal thickening, intralobular lines, architectural distortion; honeycombing signifies fibrosis.
items: Honeycombing: stacked cystic air spaces with well-defined walls (usually 3-10 mm), subpleural and basal predominance.
Traction bronchiectasis accompanies fibrotic processes (e.g., UIP/IPF).
Septal thickening + GGO with gravitational distribution suggests edema (e.g., cardiogenic).

images.caption: Honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis in UIP/IPF.
Subpleural stacked cysts typical for honeycombing.
Septal thickening + ground-glass in dependent lungs (edema).

sections.title: Ground-Glass, Crazy Paving, Consolidation
sections.description: Increased attenuation patterns.
items: Ground-glass opacity (GGO): hazy increased attenuation with preserved vessel outlines.
Consolidation: opacification obscuring vessels; air bronchograms common.
Crazy paving: GGO with superimposed septal/intralobular lines (e.g., alveolar proteinosis, edema, hemorrhage, infection).

images.caption: Crazy paving pattern in alveolar proteinosis.
Bronchoalveolar carcinoma with mixed GGO and consolidation.

sections.title: Nodular Patterns
sections.description: Differentiate by distribution: perilymphatic, centrilobular, random.
items: Perilymphatic: along pleura, fissures, peribronchovascular bundles (e.g., sarcoidosis).
Centrilobular: spares pleura/fissures; seen in HP, infection, RB-ILD; tree-in-bud when impacted bronchioles.
Random: uniform distribution, including subpleural (e.g., miliary TB, hematogenous metastases).

images.caption: Poorly defined centrilobular GGO nodules in hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

sections.title: Mosaic Attenuation / Air Trapping
sections.description: Areas of differing attenuation/lucency.
items: Causes: small airway disease (air-trapping), vascular occlusion, infiltrative ground glass.
Expiratory scans accentuate air-trapping; vessels smaller in hypoattenuated regions when perfusion reduced.
Correlate with distribution and clinical context.

sections.title: Emphysema & Low Attenuation
sections.description: Patterns of decreased attenuation.
items: Centrilobular emphysema: lucencies centered on respiratory bronchioles, sparing pleura.
Paraseptal emphysema: subpleural/bullous lucencies along septa and pleura.
Panlobular emphysema: diffuse low attenuation with uniform vessel attenuation (e.g., alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency).

images.caption: Centrilobular emphysema sparing the pleural surface.

sections.title: Cystic Lung Disease
sections.description: Thin- or thick-walled air-containing spaces.
items: Langerhans cell histiocytosis: upper lobe-predominant nodules -> bizarre cysts.
LAM: diffuse, thin-walled round cysts; may be complicated by pneumothorax.
Differentiate cysts from honeycombing (fibrosis) and emphysema (no wall).

images.caption: Langerhans cell histiocytosis with cystic change.

sections.title: Bronchiectasis & Airways
sections.description: Dilated airways, tree-in-bud, mucoid impaction.
items: Traction bronchiectasis signifies fibrosis; central bronchiectasis + mucoid impaction (glove-finger) in ABPA.
Tree-in-bud reflects endobronchial infection/inflammation with impacted bronchioles.
Evaluate airway caliber, wall thickening, and distribution.

sections.title: Differential Quick Tables
sections.description: Reference panels summarizing patterns and differentials.

bone-tumors.title: Bone Tumors - Differential Diagnosis
bone-tumors.source: Radiology Assistant: Bone tumors - Differential diagnosis

sections.title: Systematic Approach
sections.description: Start with patient age, lesion location (epiphysis/metaphysis/diaphysis, axial vs appendicular), and the most aggressive imaging feature.

sections.title: Zone of Transition
sections.description: Narrow zone suggests slow growth/benign; wide or ill-defined transition suggests aggressive or malignant process (including infection or EG).

images.alt: Narrow zone examples: NOF, SBC, ABC

sections.title: Periosteal Reaction
sections.description: Smooth, uninterrupted periosteal reaction is typically benign/stress/healing; aggressive patterns include lamellated, spiculated, or Codman triangle.

sections.title: Cortex and Expansion
sections.description: Evaluate cortical destruction, ballooning, and soft-tissue mass.

images.alt: Permeative cortical destruction with soft-tissue mass

sections.title: Location Patterns
sections.description: Location within the skeleton guides differential.

sections.title: Centricity
sections.description: Eccentric vs central positioning within the bone can narrow differential diagnoses.

sections.title: Matrix
sections.description: Matrix mineralization pattern (chondroid, osteoid, fibrous) aids diagnosis.

sections.title: Multiplicity
sections.description: Multiple lesions shift the differential toward metastases, myeloma, LCH, or multifocal benign entities.

sections.title: Approach
sections.description: Use a systematic ABCDE approach when evaluating arthritis on radiographs.
items: Alignment
Bone density (osteopenia/erosions)
Cartilage space (joint space)
Deformity (osteophytes, bone proliferation)
Soft tissue

sections.title: Erosions
sections.description: Erosions are focal bone loss at the joint margins-key for inflammatory arthritides.

sections.title: Alignment
sections.description: Assess for malalignment and subluxation.

sections.title: Osteophytes / Deformity
sections.description: Bone proliferation and osteophytes are typical in degenerative changes.

sections.title: Bone Density / Osteopenia
sections.description: Periarticular osteopenia suggests inflammatory arthritis; sclerosis favors degenerative disease.

sections.title: Cartilage Space
sections.description: Joint space narrowing pattern helps distinguish inflammatory from degenerative disease.

sections.title: Soft Tissue
sections.description: Evaluate for swelling, effusions, or masses.

sections.title: Case: Hand Osteoarthrosis
sections.description: Example radiograph showing degenerative changes.

lymph-node-limits.title: Upper Limit of Lymph Node Sizes in Adults
lymph-node-limits.source: Extracted from Wikipedia: Lymph node - table "Upper limit of lymph node sizes in adults"

sections.title: General and Pelvis
sections.description: General upper limits and pelvic/inguinal nodes (short-axis, unless specified).

sections.title: Neck
sections.description: Cervical lymph node size thresholds.

sections.title: Mediastinum
sections.description: Mediastinal lymph node upper limits.

sections.title: Upper Abdominal
sections.description: Upper abdominal lymph node size thresholds.

sections.title: Chest - Aorta
sections.description: Measurement of pediatric thoracic aorta on contrast-enhanced axial CT.
items: Level A: 1 cm below aortic arch
Level B: 1 cm cranial to aortic root
Level C: 1 cm cranial to dome of right hemidiaphragm
Regression charts plot mean with 95% confidence limits
Reference: Fitzgerald SW, Donaldson JS, Poznanski AK. Pediatric thoracic aorta: Normal measurements determined with CT. Radiology 1987;165:667-669.

images.caption: Levels A-C and measurement sites on thoracic aorta

images.alt: Pediatric thoracic aorta CT measurement levels
images.caption: CT sections demonstrating measurement levels

sections.title: Chest - Bronchi
sections.description: Normal bronchial measurements and visibility.
items: Bronchiectasis defined by bronchus-to-artery ratio >1.2 on chest radiographs (external diameters).
Normal bronchi are not usually seen in the most peripheral 5-10 mm of lung on CT.

References: Woodring JH. Pulmonary artery-bronchus ratios in patients with normal lungs, pulmonary vascular plethora, and congestive heart failure. Radiology 1991;179:115-22. Siegel MJ. Pediatric Body CT. 1999. p.101.

sections.title: Chest - Cardiothoracic Index
sections.description: Frontal chest radiograph at 72 inches during quiet breathing.
items: ID = internal diameter of chest at level of right hemidiaphragm
MRD = max perpendicular diameter from midline to right heart border
MLD = max perpendicular diameter from midline to left heart border
CT index = (MRD + MLD) / ID
items2: Comments: First year has larger CT index due to transverse heart position and expiratory films; infant data from supine films at 1.5 m.
References: Bakwin H, Bakwin R. Am J Dis Child 1935;49:861. Maresh MM, Washburn AH. Am J Dis Child 1938;56:33. Lincoln EM, Spillman R. Am J Dis Child 1928;35:791.

sections.title: Chest - Retropharyngeal & Retrotracheal Soft Tissues
sections.description: Measurements on lateral neck radiographs.
items: *Measured at mid-portion of C5 on lateral radiograph.
Expiration and neck flexion increase apparent thickness artifactually.
Rule of 7s: retropharyngeal <=7 mm; retrotracheal <=14 mm.
References: Hay PD Jr. Ann Roentgenol 1930. Redman HC et al. Emergency Radiology, Cervical Spine, 1993.

sections.title: Chest - Thymus
sections.description: Normal CT measurements (mean values).
items: Reference: Francis IR, Glazer GM, Bookstein FL, Gross BH. The thymus: reexamination of age-related changes in size and shape. AJR 1985;145:249-254.

sections.title: Endocrine - Thyroid
sections.description: Sonographic normal thyroid lobe measurements.
items: Reference: Cole-Beuglet C. Ultrasonography of the thyroid, parathyroid and neck masses. In: Diagnostic ultrasound: text and cases. 1987:608-618. (Modified)

sections.title: Gastrointestinal - Appendix
sections.description: Normal appendix measurements.
items: References: Kao SC et al. Acute appendicitis in children: sonographic findings. AJR 1989;153:375-379. Curtin KR et al. CT diagnosis of acute appendicitis. AJR 1995;164:905-909.

rows.description: Subcapsular 10-50% surface area; intraparenchymal <10 cm diameter
Capsular tear 1-3 cm parenchymal depth, <10 cm length
Subcapsular >50% surface area or expanding; ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma; intraparenchymal hematoma >10 cm or expanding
Parenchymal disruption involving 25-75% of hepatic lobe or 1-3 Couinaud segments
Parenchymal disruption >75% of hepatic lobe or >3 Couinaud segments within a single lobe
Juxtahepatic venous injuries (retrohepatic vena cava/central major hepatic veins)
Subcapsular 10-50% surface area; intraparenchymal <5 cm diameter
Capsular tear 1-3 cm parenchymal depth that does not involve a trabecular vessel
Subcapsular >50% surface area or expanding; ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma; intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding
>3 cm parenchymal depth or involving trabecular vessels
Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels producing major devascularization (>25% of spleen)
Hilar vascular injury that devascularizes spleen
Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
<1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
>1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
Parenchymal laceration extending through cortex, medulla, and collecting system
Main renal artery or vein injury with contained hemorrhage
Avulsion of renal hilum which devascularizes kidney
Major contusion without duct injury or tissue loss
Major laceration without duct injury or tissue loss
Distal transection or parenchymal injury with duct injury
Proximal transection or parenchymal injury involving ampulla
Blunt cardiac injury with minor ECG abnormality (nonspecific ST/T changes, premature atrial or ventricular contraction, or persistent sinus tachycardia)
Blunt or penetrating pericardial wound without cardiac injury, cardiac tamponade, or cardiac herniation

Blunt cardiac injury with heart block (RBBB/LBBB/LAFB/AV block) or ST depression/T wave inversion without cardiac failure; penetrating tangential myocardial wound up to but not through endocardium without tamponade; or sustained (>6 beats/min) multifocal ventricular contractions
Blunt pericardial laceration with cardiac herniation; penetrating tangential myocardial wound extending through endocardium with tamponade; or septal/valvular/ coronary injury without failure

Cardiac injury with septal rupture, valvular incompetence, papillary muscle dysfunction, or distal coronary occlusion producing cardiac failure; proximal coronary occlusion; right/left atrial or ventricular perforation; aortic/mitral valve incompetence
Blunt avulsion of the heart or penetrating wound producing >50% tissue loss of a chamber
Unilateral single-lobe contusion or simple pneumothorax
Unilateral contusion >1 lobe; persistent air leak (>72h) from distal airway; nonexpanding intraparenchymal hematoma
Expanding intraparenchymal hematoma or major (segmental/lobar) laceration; primary branch intrapulmonary vessel disruption
Total uncontained transection of pulmonary hilum
>10 cm laceration with tissue loss <25 cm^2
>10 cm laceration with tissue loss >25 cm^2
Pseudoaneurysm of carotid or vertebral artery
3 adjacent ribs, closed; nondisplaced sternum; scapular body closed
Open or displaced clavicle; open or displaced sternum; full thickness wound including pleural penetration
Flail sternum; unilateral flail segment (<3 ribs); chest wall avulsion with underlying rib fractures
Bilateral flail chest (>3 ribs each side)
Main pulmonary artery/vein or aortic transection with free rupture
Partial avulsion from liver bed; cystic duct intact
Gallbladder laceration or perforation; cystic duct laceration; partial right or left hepatic duct laceration; partial common hepatic/bile duct laceration (<50%)
>50% transection of common hepatic or bile duct; combined right and left hepatic duct injuries
Intradoudenal/intrapancreatic bile duct injuries or complete gallbladder avulsion
<2 cm at GE junction or pylorus; <5 cm in proximal 1/3; <10 cm in distal 2/3
>2 cm at GE junction or pylorus; >5 cm proximal 1/3; >10 cm distal 2/3
>75% of D2; involving ampulla or distal common bile duct; massive duodenopancreatic disruption
Transection with tissue loss or devascularized segment
Full-thickness with extension into perineum or devascularized segment
Non-named SMA/IMA branches, phrenic, lumbar, gonadal, other small vessels requiring ligation
Hepatic artery, splenic artery/vein, gastric arteries, gastroduodenal artery, IMA trunk, primary mesenteric branches
SMV trunk, renal artery/vein, iliac artery/vein, hypogastric artery/vein
IVC infrarenal; SMA trunk; celiac axis; IVC suprarenal; aorta infrarenal; portal vein; extrahepatic hepatic vein
IVC retrohepatic/suprahepatic; aorta suprarenal; massive liver + veins
Total parenchymal destruction or avulsion from blood supply
Intraperitoneal >2 cm or extension into bladder neck/ureteral orifice
Extravasation at injury site with bladder visualization; <2 cm separation
Extravasation without bladder visualization; <2 cm separation
Complete transection with >2 cm separation or extension into prostate/vagina
Superficial laceration (<1 cm) with placental abruption <25%
Deep laceration (>1 cm) in 2nd trimester or abruption 25-50%
Deep laceration (>1 cm) in 3rd trimester or >50% abruption; involving uterine artery
Uterine rupture or complete placental abruption
Partial disruption or blood supply loss
Deep laceration into fat or muscle
Injury into adjacent organs (anus, rectum, urethra, bladder)
Deep laceration into fat or muscle
Injury into adjacent organs (anus, rectum, urethra, bladder)
Tunica albuginea laceration with <50% parenchymal loss
Tunica albuginea laceration with >50% parenchymal loss
Buck fascia (corpora) laceration without tissue loss
Laceration through glans/meatus; cavernosal or urethral defect <2 cm; partial penectomy
Cavernosal or urethral defect >2 cm; total penectomy
Digital/palmar/plantar/pedal small arterial or venous injuries; basilic/cephalic/saphenous veins
Axillary vein; superficial/deep femoral vein; popliteal vein
Superficial/deep femoral, popliteal, axillary, common femoral arteries
Transection or combined arterial/venous loss with limb threat

frequents.routineSmsTemplate: {firstName}, its me Zahir from Radiology. Its {time} on {date}. I would like to discuss routine priority results with you regarding a patient you referred to us. Please give me a call at your convenience.
frequents.urgentSmsTemplate: {firstName}, its me Zahir from Radiology. Its {time} on {date}. I would like to discuss urgent priority results with you regarding a patient you referred to us. Please give me a call at your earliest convenience.
